School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Guizhou University Guiyang 550025 PR China The rational design of efficient polar heterogeneous catalysts for oxidation adsorption desulfurization (OADS) is still a challenge. Herein, we fabricated a novel polar fingerprint-like heterogeneous catalyst (HPW-NH2-CPRNSs) by immobilizing phosphotungstic acid on amino grafted phenolic resin nanospheres prepared through gradient temperature hydrothermal method, which exhibits highly effective oxidative-adsorptive desulfurization (OADS) performance. The fingerprint-like nanospheres catalysts were formed when the F127 exposed on the surface of PRNSs was dissolved during the refluxing. Moreover, the polarity of the HPW-NH2-CPRNSs catalysts can be well adjusted by controlling the amount of amino grafting and calcination temperature, which plays an important role in OADS. The removal rate of DBT on optimal polar catalyst reached the highest 98.9% in 90 min. It is the first time that this work involving the phenolic resin polymers have been used as the carrier of desulfurization catalyst and the polarity of the catalyst has been artificially controlled for OADS. Graphical Abstract A novel phenolic resin-based catalyst (HPW-NH2-CPRNSs) with controllable polarity and fingerprint-like appearance was successfully synthesized as both catalyst and adsorbent for highly effective and stable oxidative-adsorptive desulfurization. ga1 Keywords Polar heterogeneous catalysts Fingerprint-like composites Phosphotungstic acid immobilized HPW-NH2-CPRNSs Oxidative-adsorptive desulfurization 1 Introduction In recent years, deep desulphurization of diesel fuel processing have attracted increasing attention worldwide due to the ecological requirements that the sulfur in motor fuels should not exceed 10 ppm [1–4]. Oxidative desulfurization (ODS) as a promising process is widely used for removing sulphur-containing compounds in fuel oils due to its mild operation conditions, low energy consumption and high efficiency in removing refractory aromatic sulfur compounds [5–8]. In the ODS process, polyoxometalates (POMs), especially Keggin-type structure H3PW12O40 (HPW), have been used as excellent catalysts due to their excellent redox potential, controllable composition, and strong acidity [9–11]. Nevertheless, pure POM is easily soluble in polar solvents and their active sites were lower exposure to the reactants, which leads to inadequacy in the catalytic performance and recyclability [12–15]. In this case, POM is usually immobilized on a suitable solid support [16,17], such as porous materials [17], carbon materials [18,19] and metal-organic frameworks [20] to improve their activity and regeneration. However, the ODS process is often accompanied with extraction by using organic solvents including ionic liquids [21], ethanol [22,23] and acetonitrile [24], which will result in environmental pollution and increasing the operation and costs of desulfurization process. Oxidation adsorption desulfurization (OADS) as an emerging class of desulfurization technology was developed on the basis of ODS, in which the catalytic materials with large polar groups play the roles as both catalysts and adsorbents [25,26]. Recently, some researches on OADS were reported for removing sulfur compounds in fuel oils without an extractant. For example, the graphene oxide modified by carboxyl group showed good OADS performance, and its sulfur removal rate reached 95% in 300 min [25]. Similarly, PW-H3N+-SBA-15 catalyst can achieve 100% desulfurization rate in 120 min, which was attributed to the polarity of the catalyst [27]. Our previous work developed an effective and stable OADS composite (HPW-NH2-HHSS) and proposed a theory that polar groups (such as -OH and -NH2) of catalysts replace polar solvents to adsorb sulfur oxidation products [28]. It is obvious that the advantage of OADS process, including no extractant, less desulfurization operation and lower cost, led to good deep desulfurization application prospect in fuel oil. So far, in addition to the above carriers, mixed matrix of Al2O3-TiO2 [29], silica@C-dots/phosphotungstates core-shell microsphere [30] and mesoporous titanosilicate [31] are used for OADS. Inspired by our previous work and theory [28], more carriers with suitable polar groups should be developed for OADS. Phenolic resins (PR) polymers have a wide range of potential applications, due to its advantages of high flame retardancy, stable performance, low cost, etc [32,33]. Phenolic resin nanospheres (PRNSs) were used for preparing mesoporous carbon nanospheres and hollow nanospheres with high surface area through carbonization of the polymer spheres [34]. After carbonization at high temperature, no functional groups are retained on PRNSs, which makes it difficult to functionalize. Recently, amine-functionalized phenolic resin was reported in situ reduction m-nitrophenol and aqueous formaldehyde as the monomers and was supported metal nanoparticles for catalytic applications [35,36]. We considered that the calcined phenolic resin nanospheres (CPRNSs) at lower carbonization temperature may have potential for OADS due to its suitable polarity. As far as we know, the research on PR-based catalyst for OADS has not been reported. Herein, we proposed a series of novel polar fingerprint-like PR catalysts (HPW-NH2-CPRNSs) for the OADS system. PRNSs were prepared by gradient temperature hydrothermal method as catalyst support. The phenolic resin system turned into colloid at 100 ℃, and then the colloidal particles aggregate into larger solid particles to form PRNSs at higher temperature (170 ℃). After amino modification of PRNSs by grafting APTMS, the HPW was immobilized on NH2-PRNSs to obtain the HPW-NH2-PRNSs, and then, HPW-NH2-CPRNSs were gained by calcining the sample at 350 ℃. An interesting finding is that the polarity of the catalyst can be adjusted by tuning the grafting amount of amino groups and controlling the calcination temperature. The HPW-NH2-CPRNSs with APTMS: PRNSs mass ratio of 1:1 and calcination temperature of 350 ℃ exhibit high desulfurization performance with the removal rate of 98.9% in 90 min without an extraction reagent. Furthermore, the mechanism and process of catalytic oxidation adsorption desulfurization were studied. To the best of our knowledge, it is the first time to design efficient polar heterogeneous catalysts rationally for the OADS system in fuel oil. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials In this work, triblock copolymer Pluronic F127 was purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Potassium chloride (KCl, AR) was purchased from Chengdu Jinshan Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Concentrated sulfuric acid (H2SO4, AR) was purchased from Chuandong Chemical. Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, AR) was purchased from Kermel. Trimethylbenzene (AR), toluene (AR), anhydrous ethanol, hydroquinone, formaldehyde, 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (APTMS, AR), phosphotungstic acid H3PW12O40 (HPW), dibenzothiophene (DBT, 98％, AR) and n-octane (C8H18, AR) were purchased from Macklin. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of phenolic resin nanospheres (PRNSs) We proposed the gradient temperature hydrothermal method to prepare PRNSs ( Scheme 1), the preparation process is as follows. 2 g of Pluronic F127, 0.4 g of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) and 2 g of KCl were added to 120 mL of 1 M H2SO4. Then 2 mL of trimethylbenzene, 24 mL of absolute ethanol and 0.8 g of resorcinol were added. After all the solids were dissolved, 1.12 mL of formaldehyde was added. After stirring at 31 ℃ for 24 h, the reaction liquid was poured into the crystallization kettle. The gradient temperature hydrothermal processes were adapted with reaction at 100 ℃ for 8 h (Scheme 1 Step 1), then at 170 ℃ for 12 h (Scheme 1 Step 2). After step 1, the system turned into colloid, hence the solid products cannot be obtained by centrifugation. When the second step of crystallization is completed, colloidal particles aggregate into larger solid particles, separated by filtration. The filtrated residue was washed with deionized water to neutral and then dried at 80 ℃ for 24 h to obtain PRNSs with smooth surface. 2.2.2 Preparation of amine functionalized phenolic resin nanospheres (NH2-PRNSs) The functionalization of PRNSs was realized by grafting 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (APTMS, AR) onto PRNSs. In detail, 0.5 g of PRNSs was dispersed in toluene, and 0.5 g of APTMS was added under stirring. This solution was then refluxed and stirred at 110 ℃ for 12 h. The solid products were separated by centrifugation, washed with anhydrous ethanol, and dried at 80 ℃. This product was named as NH2-PRNSs (1:1). The NH2-PRNSs samples with different mass ratios of APTMS/PRNSs = 0.25:1, 0.5:1, 1.5:1 were prepared in the same way. All of them have smooth surface. 2.2.3 Preparation of catalyst HPW-NH2-CPRNSs Firstly, 0.4 g of NH2-PRNSs with different grafting amounts of amino groups was dispersed in 20 mL anhydrous ethanol, and then 0.1 g of HPW was added. Subsequently, this mixture was ultrasonically mixed for 15 min, refluxed at 70 ℃ for 2 h, and then evaporated to dryness. The obtained HPW-NH2-PRNSs were calcined at 350 ℃ under N2 flow for 3 h. The final catalysts were named HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (0.25:1), HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (0.5:1), HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1), HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1.5:1) according to the APTMS: PRNSs mass ratio. All these catalysts have the fingerprint-like surface, which was formed when the exposed F127 on the surface of PRNSs was washed away by ethanol. The overall process of catalyst preparation is shown in Scheme 2. 2.3 Catalytic oxidative-adsorptive desulfurization experiments Preparation of simulated oil: 0.432 g DBT was fully dissolved in 250 mL n-octane to obtain simulated oil with DBT concentration of 300 ppm. The simulated oil of 100 ppm, 200 ppm, 400 ppm and 500 ppm were prepared by the same method. The OADS process was carried out in a 250 mL flask, in which 10 mL of simulated oil (300 ppm) was dripped, and then a certain amount of H2O2 (30%) and 60 mg of catalyst were added to the flask under magnetic stirring. To study the influence of different dosage of H2O2 on the process of OADS, catalytic oxidation adsorption desulfurization experiments were carried out with different n[O] / n[S]. After 3 h of desulfurization reaction, the reaction solution was centrifuged, the supernatant was clean oil. Based on the analysis of the microcoulometric detector (WK-2D), the desulfurization rate is calculated with the following formula: η = [ ( C 0 - C ) / C 0 ] × 100 % where η represents DBT conversion, C0 and C refer to sulfur compounds concentration before and after desulfurization, respectively. The weight of the catalyst was kept constant (70 mg). The corresponding results are shown in Fig. 6A. When the reaction time is 90 min at 60 °C, the desulfurization rate of the sample is 11.90%, 37.05%, 98.90% and 6.26%, respectively. Obviously, HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (APTMS: PRNSs = 1:1) have the highest catalytic performance. The grafting amount of amino group makes a great impact on the catalytic performance of the catalyst. With the increase of amino group content, the DBT removal rate increases first and then decreases. As the APTMS: PRNSs was 1:1, the DBT removal rate of catalyst was the best, which was related to its polarity. The amino-functionalized catalyst system has various catalytic active sites and polar groups (-OH and -NH2) act as adsorption sites in the OADS system. The number of polar groups determines the polarity of the catalyst, which means that the polarity of the catalyst should not be too large or too small. If the polarity of the catalyst is too large, the catalyst will quickly combine with polar hydrogen peroxide and cannot effectively combine with sulfur compounds, affecting the catalytic performance. If the polarity of the catalyst is too small, it means that the adsorption sites of the catalyst are greatly reduced and some oxidized sulfur compounds cannot be adsorbed, which will reduce the removal rate of sulfur compounds. According to the experimental results, APTMS: PRNSs = 1:1 is the optimal amount of amino grafting. 3.2.2 Effects of different catalysts After determining the optimum amount of amino grafting, the catalytic performance of different catalysts was studied (Fig. 6B). The desulfurization efficiency of CPRNSs (calcined at 350 ℃) was only 2.03%, and that of NH2-CPRNSs (1:1) (calcined at 350 ℃) was 2.34% (Fig. 6B). Because there are no catalytic active sites on CPRNSs and NH2-CPRNSs, DBT cannot be oxidized to corresponding sulfone or sulfoxide. And DBT has weak polarity so that it cannot be adsorbed by CPRNSs or NH2-CPRNSs, hence the desulfurization efficiency of CPRNSs and NH2-CPRNSs is weak. Although phosphotungstic acid has multiple active sites which can oxidize DBT, desulfurization efficiency of pure HPW is lower (Fig. 6B) due to no adsorbent and extractant in OADS process. The desulfurization efficiency of HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1) is 98.9%, indicating that the catalysts had high catalytic activity. Above characterizations and the desulfurization results revealed that the HPW as catalytic centers and -NH2 and -OH as adsorption centers were well constructed on HPW-NH2-CPRNSs which acts as both catalysts and adsorbents in OADS process. In addition, whether the HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1) are calcined or not and the calcination temperature will also make the catalytic activity of the catalyst different (Fig. 6C). The results reflect that the desulfurization efficiency of catalyst calcined at 350 ℃ is 98.9% within 90 min, while the DBT removal rate of uncalcined catalyst is only 16.21% within 90 min. The reason for the poor catalytic performance of the uncalcined catalyst is that the polar groups (-OH and -NH2) on the surface of the catalyst are not calcined, resulting in high polarity of the catalyst. The catalyst will quickly combine with polar hydrogen peroxide and cannot effectively combine with sulfur compounds, affecting the catalytic performance. In order to confirm that some polar groups on the surface of the catalyst calcined at 350 ℃ were burned off, we tested the uncalcined catalyst by XPS and compared the XPS results with those of the catalyst calcined at 350 ℃ (Fig. S2). It can be seen from Fig. S2a that O/C atomic ratios reduced after calcination at 350 ℃, indicating that the content of O in the catalyst decreased after calcination, which is consistent with the results of TGA analysis (Fig. 3C). Furthermore, Fig. S2d shows that H-O/W-O content ratio of the catalyst decreases after calcination at 350 ℃, which further indicates that the decrease of O 1s peak intensity after calcination is due to the reduction of -OH groups. Besides, Fig. S2b, c and e showed that the N, P and W atomic orbitals maintain the same peak position before and after calcination of catalyst at 350 ℃, indicating that the atomic structures and bonding configurations did not change. The desulfurization efficiency of catalyst calcined at 500 ℃ is 86.06% within 90 min. According to TGA analysis, when calcined at 500 ℃, the polar groups (-OH and -NH2) on the surface of the catalyst are burned, which causes the decrease of the polarity of the catalyst. This will reduce the adsorption capacity of the catalyst and lead to the decrease of desulfurization rate. The photographs of the catalysts with different calcination temperature are shown in Fig. S3. It can be seen from the figure that the catalyst changed from brown to black color with increasing the calcination temperature from 350 ℃ to 500 ℃, indicating that the catalyst changes from partial carbonization to complete carbonization. 3.2.3 Effects of [O]/[S] mole ratios, catalyst dosage and reaction temperature The dosage of oxidant makes a great impact on the efficiency of desulfurization in the OADS system. A series of experiments were carried out with different n[O]/n[S] to prove the effect of oxidation dose. The effects of H2O2 / DBT molar ratios of 3:1, 4:1, 5:1, 6:1 and 7:1 on DBT conversion rate were studied under the same conditions (Fig. S4). The efficiency of desulfurization will increase sharply with the increase of n[O]/n[S] from 3:1–6:1, and beyond this ratio, the desulfurization efficiency will decrease (Fig. S4). The reason is that increasing the amount of H2O2 will improve the efficiency of oxidation, however, if the amount of H2O2 exceeds the optimal amount, the catalyst will quickly combine with polar hydrogen peroxide and cannot effectively combine with sulfur compounds, affecting the catalytic performance. The actual amount of H2O2 added is greater than stoichiometry, because H2O2 would decompose under heating conditions. To sum up, we choose the best [O]/[S] = 6:1. To obtain the maximum desulfurization efficiency, the effects of different amount of catalyst (50–80 mg) in the OADS system were studied. As shown in Fig. S5, when the amount of catalyst is 50–70 mg, the efficiency of desulfurization increases from 70% to 98.9% in 90 min, and from 73% to 99.21% after 90 min. When the amount of catalyst was 70–80 mg, the efficiency of desulfurization increased slowly from 98.9% to 99.06% within 90 min with the extension of reaction time. After 90 min, the efficiency of desulfurization both reached 99.21%. It can be seen from Fig. S5 that increasing the amount of catalyst can improve the desulfurization rate, this is because of the increased catalytic active sites, which is related to the adsorption efficiency. Nevertheless, when the amount of the catalyst further increased to 80 mg, the desulfurization efficiency increased slightly, which indicates that the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for sulfur-containing compounds may have reached saturation. Therefore, the optimal amount of catalyst is 70 mg. The reaction temperature is another important factor affecting the desulfurization reaction (Fig. S6). The results show that the efficiency of desulfurization is directly related to temperature. At 40 ℃, the efficiency of desulfurization was only 55.21% in 90 min. At 60 ℃, the efficiency of desulfurization reached 98.9% at 100 ℃. The reason is: with the increase of temperature, a large amount of W(O2) n in HPW active compound is formed, which leads to the formation of peroxide metal complexes, this can improve the oxidation ability of sulfur compounds [23]. However, high temperature will increase the cost of desulfurization. Therefore, the optimal reaction temperature in the OADS system is 60 ℃. 3.2.4 Adsorption capacity of catalyst To study the adsorption capacity of HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1), 70 mg catalyst was added to the simulated oil with different DBT concentrations (100–500 ppm). The experimental results indicate that the conversion rate of DBT decreases with the increase of DBT concentration ( Fig. 7A). The results show that 300 ppm is the best concentration to reflect the high conversion (> 98%) of DBT in 90 min because the content of DBTO2 on the catalyst is lower than the maximum adsorption capacity. The adsorption capacity of DBTO2 was calculated by the following formula: q e = ( C 0 − C e ) × V m × M D B T O 2 M S where qe, C0 and Ce represent the adsorption capacity of the catalyst (mg g−1), the initial and equilibrium concentrations of S (ppm), respectively. m, M, MS and V represent the mass of the catalyst, the molecular weight of the compound, the molecular weight of sulfur atom (32 g mol−1) and the volume of oil (L), respectively. According to Fig. 7B, the adsorption capacity of HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1) is about 286.12 mg g−1. 3.2.5 Stability of catalyst The recovery stability of the catalyst is very significant in industrial application. The desulfurized catalyst HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1) was washed with acetonitrile and recycled ( Fig. 8A). The desulfurization efficiency of HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1) decreased from 98.9% to 94.46% after five cycles. The FT-IR spectrum (Fig. 8B) showed 5 recycled catalyst maintained the characteristic bands of the fresh catalyst. The peaks of the reused catalyst appeared at 1165 and 1290 cm−1, corresponding to the SO symmetric and asymmetric tensile vibrations of DBTO2, respectively. The XRD patterns (Fig. 8C) of fresh and recycled catalyst have no obvious change, indicating that the used catalyst which completely cleaned with acetonitrile solution maintained its original structure. The reusability of HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1) catalyst is due to the interaction between the positive charge of amino groups and the negative charge of phosphotungstic acid, which weakens the solubility of phosphotungstic acid in polar solvents. In addition, scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and element mapping images of 5 recycled catalyst are shown in Fig. S7. As shown in Fig. S7a, after 5 recycled, the catalyst still appears as spherical particles, which shows that the morphology of the catalyst is not damaged after recycling. Fig. S7c-f reflected that N, O, P and W were evenly distributed on the surface of reused catalyst, indicating that -NH2 and HPW still exist in catalyst after 5 recycled. This further shows that HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1) catalyst has great recovery stability. Fig. S7g showed that S element exists on the surface of 5 recycled catalyst, indicating that the catalyst recycled 5 times still has the ability to adsorb sulfur-containing compounds. 3.3 OADS mechanism To prove the polarity of the catalyst, the water contact angle (WCA) was measured. The WCA test of the catalysts with different grafting amounts of amino groups is shown in Fig. 9A-D. The WCAs of HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (0.25:1), HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (0.5:1), HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1), HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1.5:1) are 89.29°, 62.89°, 46.90° and 37.38°, respectively. With the increase of amino grafting amount, the water contact angle decreased gradually. According to the principle of the dissolution in the similar material structure, the smaller the water contact angle, the greater the polarity of the sample. The WCA results indicate that the grafting amount of amino groups is closely related to the polarity of the catalyst, the polarity of the catalyst increased with the amino grafting amount. Moreover, we also measured the water contact angle of the catalysts calcined at different temperatures, the results are shown in Fig. S8. The figure indicated that the contact angle of uncalcined catalyst HPW-NH2-PRNSs (1:1) is the smallest, which is 32.64°. The water contact angles of catalyst calcined at 350 ℃ and 500 ℃ are 46.90° and 60.11° respectively. According to the results, the higher the calcination temperature, the smaller the polarity of the catalyst. The reason is that the polar groups (-OH and -NH2) on the surface of the catalyst will decompose at high temperature. The water contact angle data of the catalysts calcined at different temperatures were consistent with the results of TGA and XPS. The influence of catalyst polarity in the OADS system is also proved by the experiments (Fig. S9 and S10). Experimental samples are catalysts with different amounts of amino grafting and catalysts with different calcination temperature. The experimental procedure is as follows: inject n-octane into the small reagent bottle until it is added to 2/3 of the reagent bottle approximately, then drop 1 mL H2O2 and 20 mg different catalysts, stir the solution for half a minute and let it stand for one minute. Photography illustration of the dispersion degree of different catalysts in solution is shown in (Fig. S9 and S10). As can be seen from Fig. S9, HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (0.25:1), HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (0.5:1) and HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1) were well dispersed in the solution, while HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1.5:1) aggregated in the lower layer (hydrogen peroxide layer) of the solution. This phenomenon implied that HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1.5:1) catalyst has large polarity, resulting in the catalyst’s inability to contact the oil phase. These phenomena confirm the polarity mechanism of catalysts with different amounts of amino grafting again. As shown in Fig. S10, HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1) calcined at 350 ℃ and 500 ℃ were evenly dispersed in the solution, however, HPW-NH2-PRNSs (1:1) aggregated in aqueous phase (H2O2). This indicates that uncalcined catalyst HPW-NH2-PRNSs (1:1) has high polarity, which is consistent with the previous statements. Furthermore, the adsorption process of DBT was studied by GC-MS. After desulfurization for 30 min, the HPW-NH2-CPRNSs sample was separated from the oil by centrifugation and immersed in acetonitrile. As shown in Fig. 10, one peak which belongs to DBTO2 (Fig. 10A) is observed, which is corresponded to the 216.1 (m/z) peak in the mass spectrum(Fig. 10B). The results indicated that DBT was completely oxidized to sulfone, subsequently, the DBTO2 was adsorbed by HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1) catalyst. However, DBTO was not detected in the final catalyst, indicating that the oxidation products of DBT (DBTO and DBTO2) were successfully adsorbed on the surface of the nanoscale catalyst, and the DBTO was immediately oxidized to DBTO2 [23]. In addition, the catalytic oxidation and adsorption process of DBT was studied by FT-IR spectroscopy (Fig. S11). The peaks of the catalyst after desulfurization for 30 min appeared at 1165 and 1290 cm−1, corresponding to the SO symmetric and asymmetric tensile vibrations of DBTO2, respectively. There is no obvious characteristic peak of DBT in the spectrum of the catalyst, which is consistent with the result of GC-MS. The results showed that DBTO2 existed in the used HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (1:1) catalyst. According to the above results, the desulfurization mechanism of HPW-NH2-CPRNSs system was described in Scheme 3. Chen et al. [28] concluded that the smaller the particle size of the catalyst, the better the catalytic effect of removing sulfur compounds from fuel. The particle size of the catalyst prepared in this work is only about 150 nm, which enhances the desulfurization performance of the catalyst. By adjusting the content of -NH2 in the catalyst, we can control the polarity of the catalyst to a suitable value (APTMS: PRNSs = 1:1, the polarity of the catalyst is moderate) to achieve the best desulfurization effect of the catalyst. According to the comparison of different catalysts mentioned above, it can be proved that phosphotungstic acid is used as catalytic centers, CPRNSs and NH2-CPRNSs provide polar groups to adsorb oxidized sulfur-containing compounds. The catalyst and polar groups act as both catalysts and adsorbents in OADS process. The desulfurization mechanism is as follows. Firstly, the catalyst with moderate polarity dispersed evenly in the simulated oil so that DBT had more opportunities to contact the active sites effectively. Then, DBT reacted with H2O2 to form DBTO on nano-sized NH2-CPRNSs with HPW as the catalyst. Subsequently, DBTO, as a polar compound, was adsorbed by HPW-NH2-CPRNSs via hydrogen bonding with polar groups (-OH and -NH2), and the adsorbed DBTO is then oxidized to DBTO2 immediately. Because the polarity of DBTO2 is greater than that of DBTO, it can be better adsorbed by the catalyst and removed. We also compared the activity of HPW-NH2-CPRNSs with reported studies as shown in Table 2. The results show that our catalyst has certain performance advantages, and the particle size of our catalyst is relatively small. More importantly, phenolic resin was used as catalyst carrier in OADS system for the first time, which has great material innovation. 4 Conclusion In this work, the novel polar heterogeneous fingerprint-like phenolic resin nanospheres catalyst (HPW-NH2-CPRNSs) has been synthesized for OADS in fuel oil. PRNSs were prepared by gradient temperature hydrothermal method with co-template (CTAB and F127), and it is the first time that the phenolic resin polymer has been used as the carrier of desulfurization catalyst. The polarity of the catalysts can be effectively controlled by adjusting the amount of amino grafting and controlling their calcination temperature. The polarity of different catalysts was confirmed by measuring water contact angle and carrying out a series of experiments. Moreover, the influences of different factors on the desulfurization efficiency were studied, including the reaction time, amount of catalyst, the molar ratio of [O]/[S], initial concentration of DBT and reaction temperature. Under the most optimal conditions, the catalytic performance of the catalyst can reach the best. The desulfurization efficiency of the HPW-NH2-CPRNSs (mass ratio of APTMS/PRNSs = 1:1, calcined at 350 ℃) could reach the highest 98.9% in 90 min, and the catalyst could maintain its catalytic performance up to 5 cycles without significant decline. The mechanism indicates that the hydrogen bonds between the oxidized sulfur-containing compounds and polar groups (-OH and -NH2) make the catalyst have excellent DBTO2 adsorption capacity (about 286.12 mg g−1), hence the catalyst has excellent commercial potential. coredata.dc:description: The rational design of efficient polar heterogeneous catalysts for oxidation adsorption desulfurization (OADS) is still a challenge. Herein, we fabricated a novel polar fingerprint-like heterogeneous catalyst (HPW-NH2-CPRNSs) by immobilizing phosphotungstic acid on amino grafted phenolic resin nanospheres prepared through gradient temperature hydrothermal method, which exhibits highly effective oxidative-adsorptive desulfurization (OADS) performance. The fingerprint-like nanospheres catalysts were formed when the F127 exposed on the surface of PRNSs was dissolved during the refluxing. Moreover, the polarity of the HPW-NH2-CPRNSs catalysts can be well adjusted by controlling the amount of amino grafting and calcination temperature, which plays an important role in OADS. The removal rate of DBT on optimal polar catalyst reached the highest 98.9% in 90 min. It is the first time that this work involving the phenolic resin polymers have been used as the carrier of desulfurization catalyst and the polarity of the catalyst has been artificially controlled for OADS.
